posts.name:
Jerry Rassamni
Jerry Rassamni
posts.content:
A Lovable Application of AI and Technology 

Open Bionics shows the true difference AI and innovation can make in people’s lives. Their prosthetics firm is revolutionizing healthcare, especially with the groundbreaking Hero Arm—powered by cutting-edge AI.
This bionic limb is changing lives across the world.

 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲'𝘀 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗶𝘁 𝗦𝗽𝗲𝗰𝗶𝗮𝗹:
 Affordable 3D Printed Design: Custom-made and budget-friendly, it makes advanced prosthetics accessible to more people.
 AI-Driven Intuition: Learns and adapts to movements, delivering a seamless and intuitive user experience.
 Empowering Independence: Designed to restore mobility and confidence, truly a life-changing innovation.

This isn’t just any prosthetic—it’s a symbol of how AI and technology can empower and inspire where it’s needed the most.

 𝗪𝗵𝘆 𝗧𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗠𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘀:
The Hero Arm shows us the incredible potential of AI in healthcare. It’s about more than just mobility; it’s about building independence and positivity for people with limb differences.

 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗧𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵𝘁𝘀:
How do you see AI reshaping healthcare and accessibility? Share your views below!

 𝗙𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗼𝘄 𝗺𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗶𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁𝘀 𝗼𝗻 𝗔𝗜 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗶𝗻𝗻𝗼𝘃𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻!

comments.commentText: The idea of leveraging technology to improve patient engagement is critical, especially as healthcare becomes more patient-centric. Have you explored using AI for automating appointment reminders or streamlining admin tasks? It’s been a game-changer for some of the teams we work with. Would love to connect and share ideas!

AI-driven prosthetics like the Hero Arm truly highlight how technology can transform accessibility.  
How soon do you think these innovations will become the norm in healthcare?

posts.name:
David Jarcho
David Jarcho
posts.content:
The Foundation of Effective Leadership

The following is an excerpt from my upcoming book; "A Managers Guide to Fast Track Success".

When it comes to Leadership, trust is like oxygen: invisible yet vital. Without it, every interaction suffocates under the weight of suspicion and hesitation. As a manager, your ability to lead hinges on the trust you build—not just with your team but with everyone you interact with.

Have you ever found yourself in a situation where trust has eroded to a point that decisions are second-guessed, communication is guarded, and every interaction feels like a negotiation? We’ve all been there.

Lack of trust is a clear sign of a dysfunctional company or department.
In contrast, a trust-filled environment unlocks collaboration, innovation, and a sense of shared purpose.

Trust is not just a “nice to have”; it’s the foundation upon which all effective leadership is built.

When team members trust you, they follow not because they have to, but because they want to. This willingness to align with your vision and decisions is what separates ordinary managers from transformational leaders.

Trust is earned through consistent behavior over time. Your team needs to see that your words align with your actions. Inconsistencies - saying one thing and doing another - quickly erodes confidence.

Here are some ways to build trust.

*Be Transparent:* Share your thought process when making decisions. For example, if a deadline is moved, explain why rather than simply issuing directives.

*Follow Through:* If you commit to a timeline or a task, ensure you deliver. Even small breaches, like skipping a promised one-on-one, can chip away at trust.

*Be Predictable:* Set clear expectations for communication and accountability. A team that knows what to expect from you will feel secure.

*Be Consist:* Trust is earned through consistent behavior over time. Your team needs to see that your words align with your actions. Inconsistencies—saying one thing and doing another—quickly erode confidence.

*Listen to Understand:* True listening is a rare skill, yet it’s one of the quickest ways to build trust. When you actively listen, you show your team that their opinions and feelings matter.

*Trust Your Team to Build Trust:* Micromanagement sends a clear message: “I don’t trust you to do your job.” To build trust, you must first extend it.

*Admit Mistakes & Show Humility:* Leaders who pretend to be infallible create a culture of fear and dishonesty. Admitting your mistakes shows authenticity and models accountability for your team.

Trust doesn’t just stay within your team—it ripples outward, influencing every stakeholder your team interacts with. By fostering trust, you create a foundation for collaboration, innovation, growth, and resilience.

Want more helpful tips for building a high-trust environment? Join our six-week, small group, coaching program. Next session begins on 2/11/25. Contact me on LinkedIn for more info.

posts.content:
Corporates are Gearing up for Future -
 
- 85% of employers planning to prioritize upskilling their workforce,
- 70% expecting to hire staff with new skills,
- 40% planning to reduce staff as their skills become less relevant,
- 50% planning to transition staff from declining to growing roles.
- 70% considers Analytical Thinking as essential in 2025. Followed by resilience, flexibility and agility, along with leadership and social influence.

Source: Future of Jobs Report 2025 by

Ideally you’d have prior experience with Zero Knowledge or similar. They’re open to candidates from across the US, though it would be cool if you happened to be in California for collaboration meetings with the team.

2) Distributed Systems Engineers working with
who’re intrigued by changing the way we view smart contract applications and offering a totally new way to scale. Ideal candidates would have a security oriented mindset and have experience deploying in the cloud (Docker/Kubernetes/Terraform etc). Base pay is $125-250k DOE + equity. They’re NY based but would consider candidates across the country.

I’ve already spoken to a crazy amount of incredible

posts.name:
Machine Learning Community (Moderated)
Machine Learning Community (Moderated)
posts.content:
TOP 5 Time Series Forecasting Libraries in 2025

(with Pros and GitHub Stars)

🟢 𝗡𝗶𝘅𝘁𝗹𝗮 𝗦𝗲𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗟𝗶𝗯𝗿𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀 - 𝟭𝟮𝗸 ⭐
Nixtla is a set of state-of-the-art time series forecasting methods that are embedded in a set of libraries and models, most famous are:
-> statsforecast
-> neuralforecast
-> TimeGPT

Today, Nixtla is a go-to environment to solve time series forecasting problems.

🟢 𝗗𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦 - 𝟴𝗸 ⭐
Darts offers a consistent 𝘧𝘪𝘵() and 𝘱𝘳𝘦𝘥𝘪𝘤𝘵() interface across various forecasting models, from classical methods like ARIMA to deep learning models.

This makes it easy to compare and switch between different models without needing to understand their internal workings

🟢 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗽𝗵𝗲𝘁 - 𝟭𝟴.𝟰𝗸 ⭐
Prophet is specifically designed for users with limited statistical knowledge, allowing them to easily handle seasonal effects and missing data.

Its intuitive interface makes it accessible for business applications requiring quick and interpretable forecasts.

🟢 𝗦𝗞𝗧𝗶𝗺𝗲 - 𝟳.𝟴𝗸 ⭐
SKtime provides a scikit-learn-compatible framework for time series analysis, enabling users to apply machine learning techniques seamlessly.

This integration allows for easy model tuning, validation, and deployment using familiar tools.

You can also easily use embedded scikit-learn data transformers for feature generation

🟢 𝗚𝗹𝘂𝗼𝗻-𝗧𝗦 - 𝟰.𝟲𝗸 ⭐
GluonTS is focused on probabilistic forecasting, allowing users to generate not just point forecasts but also confidence intervals.

It can also be easily integrated with Amazon SageMaker, allowing users to scale their training and deployment processes efficiently.

️ Share with network to show your interest in Time Series Modeling!

P.S. Which library do you usually use for Univariate Time Series Problems?

Credit goes to @Timur Bikmukhametov, PhD for sharing this insightful post. Thank you for your contribution!
